header_summary:
AdamISZ's blog post on [Reyify](https://reyify.com/blog/adaptors-generalised/) introduces the concept of adaptor signatures, exploring their potential to extend beyond current cryptographic limitations. The post outlines a theoretical framework for using adaptor signatures in Zero-Knowledge Proof constructions, despite practical verification challenges. It proposes a protocol allowing verification of Discrete Logarithm Equality statements through BIP340 signatures, aiming to broaden adaptor signatures' application in cryptographic protocols.

MishaKomarov discusses the implementation of Bitcoin PIPEs (Polynomial Inner Product Encryption) as a method to enable covenants in Bitcoin without a soft fork, detailed in a [research paper](https://www.allocin.it/uploads/placeholder-bitcoin.pdf). This advancement allows for the creation of sophisticated spending conditions, supporting functionalities like Zero-Knowledge Proofs and native tokens, thereby enhancing Bitcoin's versatility and security without altering its core protocol.

AntoineP addresses the complexities of executing a chain fork using specific opcodes and the pivotal role of public key recovery, as analyzed in a thread on [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/cve-2024-38365-public-disclosure-btcd-findanddelete-bug/1184/5). The discussion highlights the challenges of mutual commitments between the `scriptCode` and the signature, suggesting alternative approaches to facilitate chain forks without relying on public key recovery mechanisms.

The release of Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0, as detailed on [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin-inquisition/bitcoin/releases/tag/v28.0-inq), incorporates significant protocol enhancements including TRUC and anchor relay mechanisms, and proposes consensus changes like OP_CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY. This version, building on Bitcoin Core 28.0, aims to improve transaction handling and network security, indicating a pivotal development in Bitcoin's ongoing evolution.

recent_posts.title: Adaptor generalisation
recent_posts.summary:
- The blog explores extending adaptor signatures for on-chain verification beyond secp256k1.
- It proposes a protocol for verifying Discrete Logarithm Equality using a BIP340 signature.
- The discussion includes theoretical and practical applications of adaptor signatures in cryptography.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin PIPEs: Covenants on Bitcoin Without Soft Fork
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin PIPEs allow setting specific spending conditions on coins without a soft fork.
- These conditions enable advanced functions like ZKPs verification and restaking mechanisms.
- PIPE technology facilitates complex transactions and introduces trustless, sophisticated financial applications.

recent_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
recent_posts.summary:
- Achieving a chain fork involves complex opcode use and public key recovery importance.
- Mutual commitment between signature and `scriptCode` introduces significant complexity.
- Discussion explores bypassing mutual commitment via `ANYPREVOUT` for chain forks without public key recovery.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Inquisition 28.0 introduces TRUC support and enhances transaction processes.
- It implements BIP 119, BIP 118, and BIN-2024-1 for improved protocol flexibility and security.
- Transactions with new features need inquisition node connectivity for mining.

active_posts.title: Demonstrating Pinning Attacks under Real-World Conditions
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine advocates for "free-to-pwn" lightning nodes on mainnet to test cross-layer attacks.
- He stresses the difference between testing on mainnet versus private networks for realistic outcomes.
- The initiative aims to expose vulnerabilities and discuss the protocol's security transparently.

active_posts.title: OP_ZKP updates
active_posts.summary:
- The OP_ZKP proposal seeks to integrate Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) within Bitcoin transactions.
- A need for a ZKP scheme meeting criteria like minimal security assumptions and batched verification is highlighted.
- Future adoption considerations involve performance impacts on devices and exploring alternatives like Dory if issues persist.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of three vulnerabilities affecting Bitcoin Core <v25.0
active_posts.summary:
- Significant security vulnerabilities identified in Bitcoin Core versions before 25.0 are highlighted.
- A new vulnerability disclosure policy aims to enhance transparency and security within the Bitcoin Core community.
- Future communications will disclose vulnerabilities affecting versions before 26.0, emphasizing ongoing security efforts.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances Bitcoin Lightning Network liquidity without blockchain consensus changes.
- It incorporates Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering for efficiency and security.
- Practical deployment includes incentivizing user activity and optimizing tree structures for effective liquidity.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- The integration of miniscript and taproot in Bitcoin enhances wallet development, posing challenges with unspendable keys.
- Generating unique, indistinguishable unspendable keys remains complex, despite multiple considered approaches.
- Among proposals, using a root xpub with a random chaincode is preferable for hardware signers, though improvements are sought.

active_posts.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
active_posts.summary:
- The `utxozkp` tool advances Lightning Network privacy by proving UTXO set inclusion in zero knowledge.
- It aims for future enhancements including detailed UTXO data revelation, despite current limitations.
- Performance metrics and open feedback invitation suggest ongoing development and collaboration opportunities.

today_in_history_posts.title: Year 2038 problem and year 2106 chain halting
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core may stop working in 2038 due to a potential issue with time checking.
- The entire chain will halt in 2106 when it reaches median time 0xffffffff.
- There is uncertainty if a soft-fork can resolve these issues, affecting Bitcoin Core's future.

today_in_history_posts.title: In-protocol liquidity probing and channel jamming mitigation
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Lightning wallets use probes to find fees, temporarily locking up liquidity.
- A new protocol message could allow for fee probing without locking liquidity.
- Proposed changes may improve user experience but increase costs for honest users.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability involves establishing 50,000 off-chain entities for wide-scale transactions.
- Concepts like Utreexo optimize storage but don't fully solve centralization and scalability issues.
- Effective Layer 2 protocols and security measures are essential for Bitcoin's scalability and integrity.
